ABOUT.TITLE: About
ABOUT.1: Zahwa is an app where you show how to make things using a combination of pictures and talk. It was originally intended for talking about food preparation, but it can be used to document any procedural or how-to knowledge. Zahwa supports oral translation, in the sense that you can listen to instructions in one language before speaking them in another language, to enable more people to follow along.
ABOUT.2: Zahwa's basic function is to import a series of photos. The user then narrates the images as a form of slide-show, advancing  through the slides as they speak. The app also records touch gestures as the user speaks. This is helpful to draw attention to certain items in a picture as they are referred to in speech, and gestures can also indicate things like speed and direction.
ABOUT.3: One of our goals is to share cultural knowledge across languages. The app provides the means to perform oral translations of recipes in a manner similar to the Aikuma Android app. Zahwa is part of the Aikuma Project which seeks to employ cutting edge technologies to accelerate the documentation of endangered languages.
ABOUT.4: Zahwa is the first of a new kind of language documentation tool which we call language documentation 2.0, loosely after the Web 2.0. Traditionally, digital tools for language documentation are used by experts. With Zahwa, we hope to engage ordinary speakers of small languages. Our aim is for Zahwa to be genuinely useful to speakers by itself, but to also contribute towards a central data store. Eventually, different kinds of apps will connect to the data store.
ABOUT.5: The Zahwa app was conceived by Steven Bird at the Digital Tools and Methods Summit at the University of Melbourne in June 2016 with assistance from Amina Mettouchi. Zahwa was developed by Mat Bettinson (風茂修), a PhD candidate at the University of Melbourne.
ABOUT.6: Zahwa is supported by the ARC Centre of Excellence for the Dynamics of Language (CoEDL), the NSF Award 1423406 Language Induction meets Language Documentation: Leveraging bilingual aligned audio for learning and preserving languages (David Chiang and Steven Bird), and the Australian Government Postgraduate Award scheme (APA).
ABOUT.7: Special thanks to the Saisiyat community in rural North Western Taiwan. This project would not have been possible without their enthusiasm for maintaining their own language, and their great hospitality and patience.

FAQ.TITLE: FAQ
FAQ.Q0: How can we report a bug?
FAQ.A0: Please use the bug reports section of the Zahwa Google+ community. Thanks!
FAQ.Q1: Will there be an iPhone version?
FAQ.A1: As a hybrid app we believe this should be straightforward. We would be happy to cooperate with any developers who want to make an iPhone version.
FAQ.A2: Yes! Zahwa was built with the assumption that internet access is temporary. There are settings to select automatic, manual or Wi-Fi sync.
FAQ.Q3: Can we help translate the app into my language?
FAQ.A3: Yes please. We have followed best practices for internationalization so further localizations should be straightforward.
FAQ.A4: The entire app probably wont be open source. We plan to publish some of the components in Zahwa as open source reusable components to accelerate language app development. There will be more happening in 2018.
FAQ.A5: Zahwa has a backup/export feature that selectively exports data into a zip file. This contains all of the images, audio files and metadata in json files. If you mean accessing the synced data online, a public API is in the works. We're also planning to export Zahwa data to a traditional archive and that might be easier to interact with depending on your needs.
FAQ.Q6: What technology was used to build Zahwa?
FAQ.A6: Zahwa is an Ionic app. That means it's an Angular web app, written in Typescript, bundled with Cordova and a number of native plugins. The online database is built on Firebase and Google cloud storage.
FAQ.Q7: Since Zahwa is also available in Chinese, will it work in China?
FAQ.A7: The offline features will work but the online services aren't available in China.

HELP.TITLE: How-To
HELP.INTRO: These help guides will tell you everything you need to know about using Zahwa.

OVERVIEW.TITLE: Getting started
OVERVIEW.DESC: Start here for the basics including making your first recipe.
OVERVIEW.0: Welcome to Zahwa. There are three main tabs. The home tab displays your saved recipes.
OVERVIEW.1: The maps tab displays a map centered on you. Nearby recipes will appear on this map.
OVERVIEW.2: The third tab is the 'kitchen' where you can work on your own recipes. Press the large + button to create your first recipe.
OVERVIEW.3: This will trigger a photo picker. Select the recipe photos you wish to use.
OVERVIEW.4: In the next view you can drag the images to sort, or delete images by dragging to the bin icon.
OVERVIEW.5: If you touch an image, the larger preview window lets you choose this recipe as a cover image which others will see when your recipe appears in search and on the map.
OVERVIEW.6: After importing photos, you have completed the first step of creating a recipe. The next is to record the audio.
OVERVIEW.7: Pressing record recipe will first ask you which language are using. Start typing to see auto-complete results. Touch on the language you want then press the tick icon.
OVERVIEW.8: In the recipe recorder, you see one large image and a strip of thumbnails. Press the record button and then advance through the images as you describe your recipe.
OVERVIEW.9: You can gesture over the large image to draw attention to anything in the picture.
OVERVIEW.10: You have to record right to the last image. Then you press the tick to accept.
OVERVIEW.11: The recorder then enters review mode. Press play to hear your recipe. If you want to re-do your recording, just press the left side X.
OVERVIEW.12: Having made a recording you have completed step 2. Now all that remains is to name and 'tag' your recipe.
OVERVIEW.13: Type your recipe name, description and type in the tags box to add tags. You don't have to add the description and tags now, you can add those later if you want.
OVERVIEW.14: When you type tags, be sure to touch on the tags to select them.
OVERVIEW.15: After you press the tick, Zahwa will tell you the recipe is complete and that it has been moved to the home screen.
OVERVIEW.16: A completed recipe can still be edited and improved by touching the recipe on the home page. See the next guide on publishing and sharing.

SHARE.TITLE: Publishing and Sharing
SHARE.DESC: This guide shows how to publish and share your recipe with others.
SHARE.0: In this example, we have just completed the cheese savories recipe. The red eye icon means this recipe is not yet published. Click on the recipe to open the recipe action bar.
SHARE.1: With the recipe action menu open, press the publish button as indicated.
SHARE.2: Zahwa asks you to confirm you want to publish the recipe.
SHARE.3: The recipe is published so the red eye has vanished. Now let's share it opening the action bar again.
SHARE.4: This time we'll press the share button as indicated.
SHARE.5: Now we can choose the method to share.
SHARE.6: This is an example using Facebook.
SHARE.7: This is an example of sending a link to the recipe via a text message. The web link will open a web-based recipe player.

DISCOVER.TITLE: Finding recipes
DISCOVER.DESC: How to find exciting new recipes with the map and search features.
DISCOVER.0: Finding recipes is easy. If there's nearby recipes you'll see them on the map. Otherwise press the search icon as indicated.
DISCOVER.1: The tags and languages that appear are from nearby recipes. You can also type to search.
DISCOVER.2: Click on a tag and recipe search 'hits' will appear. You can toggle the search tags between all or any.
DISCOVER.3: Click on a recipe to view more details. Here you can press the download button. This will turn into a play button when the recipe is ready to play.

TRANSLATE.TITLE: Translate
TRANSLATE.DESC: Learn how to translate recipes into your own language.
TRANSLATE.0: Touch on a recipe to open the action bar. Select the translate icon
TRANSLATE.1: Select a language for this translation by entering a new language or touching on previously used language.
TRANSLATE.2: The translate recipe activity has a play button the left and a record button the right. Press the play button to hear the original.
TRANSLATE.3: The progress bar will move as you listen. Lift off and press again if you want to repeat what you heard.
TRANSLATE.4: When you're ready, press the record button to record your translation. You can pause and resume, or undo the recording by pressing the X button.
TRANSLATE.5: When you get to the end of the recipe, you can accept your translation
TRANSLATE.6: Zahwa will begin playing so you can review your translation. You can cancel and start again or accept to complete the recipe translation.

FORK.TITLE: Copy and Change
FORK.DESC: How to make your own version of an existing recipe.
FORK.0: Open the recipe action bar and press the copy icon.
FORK.1: Confirm you wish to use these photos.
FORK.2: You can now reorder the photos, delete photos and import new photos with the picture icon.
FORK.3: The rest of the process is just like making a new recipe.
FORK.4: Press the next step, record, and select a language.
FORK.5: Use the recipe recorder to record your voice while you step through your images.
FORK.6: Proceed recording to the last slide, then press accept. Zahwa will play a preview of the recorded recipe.
FORK.7: Name, describe and tag your recipe to finish.
FORK.8: Your new recipe will appear on the home page.
